I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed policy-
based loan (PBL) and a precautionary financing option (PFO) loan to the Cook Islands for the 
Supporting Sustainable Economic Recovery Program. 
 
2.  The program will assist the Cook Islands in restoring fiscally-sustainable growth led by the 
private sector, which has been adversely affected by the impacts of the coronavirus disease 
(COVID-19) pandemic. The program supports the government’s ongoing reforms to (i) improve 
fiscal management and sustainability, and (ii) strengthen the enabling environment for the private 
sector. Ten policy actions completed under the program address longer-term development 
constraints as well as immediate recovery needs. The reforms aim to reopen the economy, better 
manage the fiscal and cash position, improve tax compliance, promote competition, ease labor 
shortages, and improve business registration are already being implemented (paras. 23–34). 
 
3.  While the Cook Islands has taken significant steps towards reopening its borders—initially 
closed in March 2020 to prevent the entry of COVID-19—the pace of recovery from COVID-19 
impacts remain highly uncertain.1 Further shocks from COVID-19 could delay the revival of 
tourism, which is a mainstay of the economy. Any unwinding of the nascent economic recovery 
could jeopardize outcomes supported by the program, forcing the Cook Islands into a fiscal crisis, 
weakening public sector service provision (including services to the poor), and  escalating 
emigration pressure as in previous crises, with detrimental long-term development impacts. 
 
4.  The government requested $80 million  (NZ$111.08 million) in  cumulative  financing 
through a single-tranche, stand-alone PBL and a PFO loan, based on program reforms.2 The PFO 
modality  permits  deferred disbursements in  case  the  tourism  recovery is  delayed.3  The 
disbursement of $40 million equivalent under the PBL will meet the development financing needs 
for fiscal year (FY) 2022 under an expected economic recovery.4 The $40 million equivalent PFO 
loan will be made available for potential future drawdowns if conditions supporting fiscal recovery 
deteriorate, based on predefined conditions (paras. 44–47). The PFO mitigates the vulnerability 
of the Cook Islands should the recovery falter and will have a positive development impact by 
helping  ensure  the  continuity  of  public  sector  operations,  social  services  to  vulnerable 
households, and the private sector recovery (para. 40). The PFO is particularly important because 
the Cook Islands has relatively few options for financing support—it has no access to international 
credit markets, lacks developed local financial markets for government debt, is not a member of 
the International Monetary Fund (IMF) nor the World Bank, and does not have a central bank to 
provide emergency liquidity. A conventional PBL modality was selected over a countercyclical 
support facility to sustain the reform momentum and leverage additional reforms, including 
through a post-program partnership framework (PPPF); and because the government does not

II.  PROGRAM AND RATIONALE 
 
A.  Background and Development Constraints 
 
5.  Background. The Cook Islands has a population of 17,580 (in 2020) spread across 
15 remote South Pacific islands and 2 million square kilometers of ocean. It is one of the region’s 
most tourism-dependent countries—tourism receipts rose from 43.3% of gross domestic product 
(GDP) in FY2012 to 61.4% of GDP in FY2019. This led to rapid development, and basic needs 
poverty fell from 28.4% in 2006 to 8.4% in 2016.6 But growth is hampered by a small population, 
narrow economic base, high exposure to disaster and climate risks, weak business climate, 
capacity constraints, and high public administration and infrastructure costs. 
 
6.  Sound  macroeconomic  management.  Before  the  pandemic,  the  Cook  Islands 
implemented sound economic policies that contributed to an average annual GDP growth of 6.7% 
during FY2016–FY2019.7 Prudent fiscal management contributed to fiscal surpluses averaging 
4.6% of GDP in this period and helped accumulate cash reserves of $91.0 million (25.8% of 
FY2020 GDP), of which $13.0 million is protected by law to meet debt servicing requirements. 
The country seldom uses program support to meet development financing needs.8 Under the 
Cook Islands Fiscal Framework, the fiscal deficit must not exceed 1.9% of nominal GDP unless 
there is an economic shock—and the country has adhered to this framework in 19 of the 20 years 
prior to COVID-19.9 Total revenue increased from 36.4% of GDP in FY2016 to 42.3% in FY2019. 
Expenditure was contained, averaging 37.5% of GDP over FY2016–FY2019. Public debt was 
17.1% of GDP in FY2020, down from a peak of 26.4% of GDP in FY2016. 
 
7.  Economic impact of COVID-19. Despite avoiding the entry of COVID-19, the pandemic-
induced border closure caused visitor arrivals to collapse and tax collection (71.9% of FY2019 
revenue) to decline by an estimated 42.0% in FY2021, threatening a fiscal liquidity crisis.10 GDP 
fell by 5.9% in FY2020 and an estimated 26.0% in FY2021, to almost one-third below the pre-
COVID-19 levels. This, along with countercyclical support and increased health expenditures 
widened the fiscal deficit to $75.3 million (28.5% of GDP) in FY2021, diminishing available 
government cash reserves to $21.2 million (7.1% of GDP) and increasing debt to 41.9% of GDP.11 
 
5  A countercyclical support facility was not deemed an appropriate modality because the loan proceeds would not 
support a new countercyclical expenditure program. The Medium Term Fiscal Strategy (MTFS) (para. 24) commits 
the government to fiscal consolidation in FY2022–FY2025 if borders are open, and a limited continuation of previous 
support measures if borders are closed. Per ADB’s Operations Manual, “the countercyclical support facility requires 
a developing member country to have a countercyclical development expenditure program and to commit to its 
implementation.” ADB. 2021. Policies and Procedures. Operations Manual. OM D4. Manila, issued on 19 January.

8.  Quarantine-free travel. To promote recovery, the Cook Islands started quarantine-free 
travel (QFT) with New Zealand tourists on 17 May 2021. It was one of the first Pacific islands to 
establish QFT.12 It was a coordinated effort with the Government of New Zealand, led on the Cook 
Islands’ side by the Border Easement Taskforce (BET) (para. 29). QFT was suspended on 17 
August 2021 because of COVID-19 cases in New Zealand, confirming the vulnerability of QFT to 
rapid closures. Prior to the suspension, visitor arrivals in July 2021 had reached 66.7% of their 
monthly pre-pandemic record—which shows that visitor arrivals can quickly recover once QFT 
resumes, even if only open to New Zealand travelers.   
 
9.  Macroeconomic outlook. Economic growth is expected to rebound to 7.1% in FY2022, 
assuming that QFT with New Zealand restarts by December 2021 and disruptions can be avoided 
for the rest of FY2022. This scenario also assumes that the FY2022 fiscal deficit will be contained 
at 14.4% of GDP. Tourism arrivals, a key determinant of the recovery, are expected to return to 
pre-pandemic levels by FY2024. Fiscal deficits (including grants) are projected to narrow, with a 
nearly balanced budget projected by FY2023.13 As outlined in the revised Medium Term Fiscal 
Strategy (MTFS), which commits to fiscal consolidation in the near term, capital projects will be 
rescheduled if grant financing is not forthcoming (para. 24). The Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
assesses the general direction of macroeconomic policies to be satisfactory and debt to be 
sustainable, although subject to significant downside risks (para. 49).    
 
10.  Fiscal constraints. The government recognizes the weaknesses in fiscal management 
that must be overcome to support the transition from immediate recovery to sustainable growth 
(paras. 11–14). Limited fiscal space can constrain growth and economic development. While 
COVID-19 forced the government to deviate from its established fiscal parameters in the short 
term, it is important to restore a sustainable fiscal position in the medium term.  
 
11.  Deviation from fiscal rules. The FY2020 MTFS was conceived prior to COVID-19 when 
fiscal responsibility rules were consistently followed.14 The government responded to the COVID-
19 impacts with increased stimulus expenditures, deviating from its medium-term goals relating 
to fiscal deficits, expenditure ceilings, and debt (para. 6). While allowing for deviations from set 
fiscal rules when faced with a crisis, the FY2020 MTFS does not provide guidance on a return to 
fiscal responsibility rules once those rules have been breached. Since fiscal decision-making is 
fundamentally different after the COVID-19 crisis, the MTFS must be updated to ensure fiscal 
consolidation and a transition to long-term growth and sustainability. 
 
12.  Management of cash reserves. Without a central bank or access to credit markets, a 
cash liquidity crisis would disrupt essential services, public sector employment (55.8% women),

before COVID-19, present frameworks to manage monthly cash flows are underdeveloped and

13.  Tax compliance issues. After tax reforms from 2011 to 2015, the Cook Islands achieved 
a relatively high domestic revenue mobilization rate of 38.7% of GDP by FY2019. However, mixed 
compliance led to growing arrears, estimated at NZ$43.8 million in December 2020. COVID-19 
has brought hardship to many taxpayers, and it is expected that compliance risks and demand 
for taxpayer support in the face of severe business challenges will increase. Outstanding arrears 
(which have risen since the pandemic) and inadequate voluntary tax compliance constrain the 
cash position in the short term, as well as the longer-term fiscal recovery.  
 
14.  Credibility of fiscal management. Audit reports are not always produced and disclosed 
on time, posing risks to accountability and transparency.17 By November 2020, the Audit Office 
had completed audits of the financial statements of the government and all public entities until 
FY2019. However, the inability to publish audit reports without Parliament  first tabling and 
discussing them meant that 5 years of reports (para. 27) were not available to the public. Also, no 
legal framework exists to ensure the independence of the Audit Office. Audit officers are liable to 
prosecution when executing their role, potentially impairing their objectivity. 
 
15.  Private sector constraints. The private sector faces several constraints arising from 
remoteness and small size, compounded by the absence of appropriate policy and legislation to 
strengthen the business environment (paras. 16–20). COVID-19 intensified these challenges. 
Traditionally, tourism helped mitigate the effects of small domestic markets and provided private 
sector employment, especially to the 36.7% of the workforce in tourism jobs (60.5% of them 
women). While the options for diversification are limited, the private sector will play a key role in 
development and support the government's fiscal stability through increased tax collections.  
 
16.  Border management challenges. COVID-19 brought more health and preparedness 
requirements for crossing international borders. The border closures helped to prevent COVID-
19 cases domestically, but tourism was severely impacted. As any first step to recovery, cross-
border travel with the main tourism market of New Zealand (67.2% of the Cook Islands’ FY2019 
visitor arrivals) will be essential. Effective border management, establishment of QFT, and prompt 
resolution of any disruptions to QFT require the setting of policies and procedures with New 
Zealand. This is central to maintaining confidence in the Cook Islands as a COVID-19-safe travel 
destination. Before the BET was formed (para. 29), the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Immigration 
did not have the institutional capacity to assess, implement, and monitor the strict health and 
preparedness requirements to negotiate QFT with New Zealand.

17.  Labor market frictions. Labor demand outstrips supply with migrant workers (53.3% of 
them women) accounting for 18% of the estimated overall workforce in 2011, and for almost one-
third of all labor in the tourism sector.18 On top of the repatriation of foreign workers during the 
pandemic, about 5.0% of the Cook Islands residents left for New Zealand between January and 
April 2021, exacerbating labor shortages during the recovery. Work permits for migrants have 
historically been tied to individual employers who must pay  the travel  costs, a  bond, and 
government fees. Migrant workers ran the risk of having to leave the Cook Islands unless the 
original employer gave them formal consent to move to a  new employer. With businesses 
recovering at different rates, asymmetries have emerged in the local employment market—some 
businesses are unable to repatriate idle foreign workers, while others are unable to source labor. 
 
18.  Weak general immigration processes. The process for sourcing work permits is lengthy, 
non-transparent, and not codified in law. The discretionary powers of the principal immigration 
officer are broad and not open to review or appeal. Migrant workers do not enjoy the same labor 
standards as local Cook Islanders, leading to possible abuses from employers who hold permits. 
This is particularly concerning in light of the high proportion of women migrant workers in the 
tourism industry, where victims of exploitation are often unable to access a dispute resolution 
mechanism because of their vulnerable position and liability to deportation. Modernizing current 
practice and  clarifying these issues is  imperative  to  enable transparent access  to  permit 
categories, strengthen worker protections, and provide legal and process certainty to all parties. 
The first steps in this direction are being taken (paras. 30–31). 
 
19.  Administrative burden of government registry services. Business registration, annual 
lodgments, and registration of security over movable assets are cumbersome and paper-based. 
Registering a business requires assistance from lawyers and agents to physically file the right 
documentation, which increases the administrative burden and the barriers to participation, 
including for women. Moreover, with no central registry, security interests over movable assets—
such as machinery, accounts receivable, or inventory—as collateral for loans are difficult to verify, 
and act as a barrier to lending, particularly for those without fixed assets. In 2017, Parliament 
passed the Companies Act, the Personal Property Securities Act, and the Incorporated Societies 
(Amendment) Act, but their implementation remains incomplete without supporting processes, 
regulations, ability to access company records, or a central registry of movable assets.19 
 
20.  Insufficient competition in telecommunications. High costs of basic utilities pose 
challenges to businesses and reduce the competitiveness of tourism. In telecommunications, the 
monopoly provider is unregulated and provides poor connectivity at a high cost. Retail charges in 
Cook Islands are costlier than those of regional peers, but the completion of the Manatua deep-
sea cable, partly funded by ADB, brings an important opportunity for reform.20 For now, insufficient 
regulation and oversight, and the absence of retail competition still hamper service delivery, 
although improvement efforts are underway (para. 34). Competition will benefit consumers and 
businesses through lower cost, more choices, and better quality. Lower telecommunications 
prices will also benefit tourism and retail services and improve access (including for women).

B.  Policy Reform, ADB’s Value Addition, and Sustainability 
 
22.  Program description. The program will help the government transition from immediate 
recovery to fiscally sustainable growth led by the private sector by supporting two reform areas: 
(i)  improving  fiscal  management  and  sustainability,  and  (ii)  strengthening  the  enabling 
environment for the private sector. The government has progressed its longer-term reform agenda 
despite  capacity  limitations  and  the  diversion  of  resources  to  respond  to  the  severe 
socioeconomic impacts of COVID-19. Program policy actions address the government’s own 
needs and priorities, in response to policy challenges intensified by COVID-19.24 The program 
comprises 10 policy actions, all of which have been completed. 
 
23.  Reform area 1: Fiscal management and sustainability. Restoring fiscal stability is 
essential to support immediate recovery and long-term economic growth and development. This 
reform area comprises four policy actions (paras. 24–27), which were designed with ADB support, 
including in economic modeling, strategic planning, and cash and fiscal monitoring (para. 37). 
 
24.  Fiscal strategy. The cabinet approved a new MTFS for FY2022–FY2025 in October 
2021, and MFEM commenced implementation. It includes cash, debt, and fiscal targets consistent 
with preserving social protection payments, providing macroeconomic stability, and supporting 
economic growth. It aligns the government’s path with the fiscal responsibility rules (footnote 14) 
and has a cash reserve target as the principal fiscal anchor. The new MTFS is consistent with the 
FY2022 budget, which commits the government to maintain public debt below 65% of GDP, limit 
growth in operational expenditure ceilings across the forward estimates to 2% a year (or in line 
with inflation), and safeguard social protection measures for the vulnerable.25 Once the economy 
has returned to pre-pandemic levels of GDP, expected in FY2024, the MTFS targets will be 
revised to have public debt as the principal fiscal anchor.26   
 
25.  Cash management. The cabinet approved a Cash Management Strategy in October 
2021, with adjustment measures if cash reserves fall below a critical limit.27 The strategy is 
anchored on responsible fiscal management, derived from debt and fiscal targets in the MTFS.

reinforce tax  compliance, intensify the collection of arrears, and accelerate the issuance of 
refunds. So far, the division has operationalized a compliance risk register, formalized quarterly 
meetings to monitor performance, and standardized monthly manager reports. Other initiatives it 
completed are standard operating procedures for major tax processes (including collection of 
arrears), and the formation of an enterprise team that focuses on the largest 40 businesses.  
 
27.  Audit reporting. Parliament  passed amendments to the Public Expenditure Review 
Committee and Audit Act in May 2020 to improve the timeliness and transparency of audit 
reporting and protect Audit Office staff from prosecution when performing their official duties. The 
amendments allow for the publication of government audit reports 14 days after they have been 
lodged with the Speaker of Parliament regardless of whether the Public Accounts Committee has 
reviewed the reports, or whether the reports are tabled or discussed in Parliament. The Audit

28.  Reform area 2: Enabling environment for the private sector. The private sector will 
continue to be central in the immediate fiscal and economic recovery as well as the longer-term

were designed with the support of ADB, including policy, technical, and legislative support to the

29.  Border management. To support tourism recovery and employment, where women 
account for 60.5% of the workforce, the government established the multi-agency BET in April 
2021 (accountable to the Prime Minister) to oversee comprehensive steps to get the Cook Islands 
ready for QFT with New Zealand and address QFT disruptions promptly.29 The steps implemented 
under BET oversight include setting up a website to communicate COVID-19-related updates, 
launching a contact-tracing mobile application, training frontline staff in COVID-19 response 
measures (and selected health workers in administering COVID-19 vaccines), and managing the 
public alert levels for community responses. The BET is responsible for establishing policies and 
procedures with New Zealand on border management and is central to ensuring that disruptions 
to border and COVID-19 management are resolved quickly.

undertake new or secondary employment beyond their initial permit sponsor without having to

32.  Online registry. The cabinet approved regulations in December 2019 to govern digital 
business and securities registration. The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) implemented the regulations 
by establishing an integrated online platform for the filing of (and access to) company records, 
business names,  business licenses, incorporated associations,  and  for registering security 
interests over movable assets. This will improve access for entrepreneurs (including women) to 
registry services without the use of lawyers or other proxies and enable the collection of sex-
disaggregated data. The MOJ made online filing compulsory from 2020. The online registry allows 
24-7 interaction between the ministry and users, which especially benefits women, who are often 
primary caregivers with family responsibilities during office hours. The registry records securities 
in a centralized database so that lenders may determine whether a proposed borrower has 
previously pledged particular collateral to secure a previous loan. This makes risk assessments 
easier and allows lending services even when businesses lack land to be pledged as collateral. 
 
33.  Competition regulator. Parliament approved the Competition and Regulatory Authority 
Act in December 2019 and the establishment of the Competition and Regulatory Authority (CRA). 
This addressed the problem of scattered regulatory authority across different departments, 
boards, and appointees by vesting the responsibility for regulating multiple sectors in a single, 
independent, expert authority accountable to Parliament. The CRA was granted investigative, 
search, and enforcement powers as well as separate appropriations starting with the FY2022 
budget, which ensures its independence. Its chair was appointed on 31 March 2020. 
 
34.  Telecommunications reform.  Parliament  passed  the  Telecommunications  Act  in 
December 2019 to eliminate monopoly protection, allow licensing of new providers, and enable 
the regulation of wholesale prices. The act is expected to result in the entry of more service 
providers, including small and innovative niche players, to be regulated by the CRA. This will lead 
to better services and lower prices for businesses and consumers, and tourism will benefit from 
better retail service delivery. The act provides for the regulation of interconnection and wholesale 
pricing terms to facilitate market competition. The CRA issued four licenses to additional operators 
under the act to increase competitive pressure, with one licensee starting operations in 2021.

C.  Expected Outcome of the Reforms 
 
40.  The  program  aligns  with  the  government’s Economic  Development Strategy  2030 
(para. 21). The outcome will be: fiscally sustainable private-sector-led economic growth in the 
Cook Islands restored. Supported by reform area 1, it is expected that the Cook Islands will stay 
below its revised debt target, avoid a liquidity crisis, strengthen tax compliance, and improve fiscal 
sustainability for better development outcomes. Reform area 2 will support QFT, enabling a 
recovery in tourism, related employment, and business income; reduce labor shortages by 
increasing labor mobility for migrant workers; help improve immigration management; lower 
business compliance costs through the online registry; promote the use of movable capital for 
lending; and improve telecommunication services to support investment and reduce costs.38

43.  Need for precautionary financing. If the current suspension of QFT is prolonged (or 
other factors disrupt QFT in the future), the nascent recovery could unravel quickly. In that case,

escalate more quickly than the government’s ability to source other financing (para. 4).

on or after 1 April 2022, subject to the drawdown conditions (paras. 45–47).40

45.  Condition 1: Tourism arrivals. Visitor arrivals are the key driver of economic recovery. 
Tourism is a  significant contributor to domestic taxation,  which in turn drives government 
revenues, which must recover for improved macroeconomic conditions to lead to improved fiscal 
balances. Tourism data are publicly available  within 2–3 weeks of the reference period and 
represent a more efficient verification method than determining government revenue, since tax 
returns take up to 2 months after the reference period to be fully processed and reconciled.  
 
46.  The government estimates the critical level of tourism to be 130,000 cumulative visitor 
arrivals over 12 months (or 10,833 arrivals per month).41 From January 2022, monthly arrivals at 
or above this level will facilitate sufficient government revenues to support planned expenditures 
without the need for external support.42 Monthly arrivals are expected to achieve the pace required 
to meet 130,000 arrivals over a 12-month period soon after QFT is restored, and be maintained 
above this level thereafter.43 However, if the number  of visitor arrivals is below this level, the Cook 
Islands will likely require additional support from development partners or through the PFO loan.

then the government needs to show that the average monthly number of visitor arrivals

PFO loan is below the critical figure of 10,833 visitors per month;44 or  
(ii)  If the request for drawdown is submitted after 1 January 2023, then the government 
needs to show that the number of cumulative visitor arrivals over the 12-month period 
preceding the submission of a request for withdrawal is less than 130,000 visitors.   
 
47.  Condition 2:  Continued satisfaction of  policy  actions and  continued sound 
macroeconomic management. For the PFO loan to be disbursed, the government must (i) show 
that all  policy actions under the program continue to be complied with, without reversals of

the past 2  years, whichever is greater), in line with the revised MTFS; (b) applying measures for 
addressing a liquidity crisis as set out in the Cash Management Strategy; and (c) utilizing all non-
debt financing options available to meet government financing needs.45
